channel.title: XFS vs JFS
channel.description: Which one is the better file system and why?

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

True, any system can be corrupted.

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

@solarwind
I have had harddrive motors die (external drives that have fallen).
I have had file corruption on linux boxes when power plugs has been pulled up or power lost.
I think file corruption on power loss can happen on all file systems some have smaller timeframes where corruption would occur.

correction to my last post. “Hard to interactive with from a Windows Machine at this time.”

Solaris does have CIFS service now. So it is easy to pass files from my windows boxes to it. on windows its called “map network drive”.

Before it had NFS which ment i needed Window vista utlimate or enterprises to use.

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“ruler, post:14, topic:202550”]ZFS > Most

I use ZFS on a open solaris box.

Good:
Awesome feature set, multiple expandable file system by just adding drives, self-healing
gzip compression option on file systems.
Mature Solaris Kernel
Free
Cheap alternative to other similar hardware options
load balances devices

bad:
Not a mature file system, relativly new.
Hard to interactive with from a Windows Machine at this time.
Not many users.
Clustering not as good as it can be.
Eats alot of RAM.
Uses alot of CPU. not so much imo
No marketing.
Needs to be Scrubed sorta like

Has alot other features / support that are more for techies but not for me
cache devices,
usb thumbdrives / hard drives
seperate logging devices[/quote]
I’ve never had a problem with Ext3 in my life. Most reliable filesystem I have ever used.

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:11, topic:202550”][quote author=solarwind link=topic=267216.msg2215225#msg2215225 date=1210053097]

Ext 3 fragments.

It is defragged on the fly, so you never have to worry about it.
Funny how on the fly defragging in Linux has been around since 1994, yet windows has yet to implement it.

People talk like they know - when they don’t. Ext 3 fragments. End of story. Almost ALL filesystems fragment. Some are more prone to it than others. And some are just flawed (like all windows filesystems).
[/quote]
I never said it didn’t fragment, I said it is automatically defragmented behind the scenes, so you never have to worry about fragmentation.[/quote]
Sorry, I misunderstood you.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: May 05, 2008, 09:16:44 PM[/size][hr][quote=“Moparisthebest, post:12, topic:202550”][quote author=http://www.tldp.org/LDP/sag/html/filesystems.html]
Modern Linux filesystem keep fragmentation at a minimum by keeping all blocks in a file close together, even if they can’t be stored in consecutive sectors. Some filesystems, like ext3, effectively allocate the free block that is nearest to other blocks in a file. Therefore it is not necessary to worry about fragmentation in a Linux system.
[/quote]

That is a great website to reference when choosing a filesystem, also have a look at this extensive comparison page:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_file_systems[/quote]
Gotta love those links. Thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

http://www.tldp.org/LDP/sag/html/filesystems.html:

Modern Linux filesystem keep fragmentation at a minimum by keeping all blocks in a file close together, even if they can’t be stored in consecutive sectors. Some filesystems, like ext3, effectively allocate the free block that is nearest to other blocks in a file. Therefore it is not necessary to worry about fragmentation in a Linux system.

That is a great website to reference when choosing a filesystem, also have a look at this extensive comparison page:

en.wikipedia.org

Comparison of file systems

The following tables compare general and technical information for a number of file systems. In POSIX namespace: any UTF-16 code unit (case-sensitive) except / as well as NUL Experimental port available to 2.6.32 and later

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Ext3 never fragments, so there is no need for a defrag tool. Plus, I have a bunch of small files and a bunch of big ones. What about symbolic link support?

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:202550”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=267216.msg2206899#msg2206899 date=1209580329]
Have you considered Reiser?
[/quote]

The murderous file system? (haha, if you don’t get it, google ‘reiser murder’) edit: solarwind beat me

I’ve always just stuck with ext3, let me know what you discover though.[/quote]
I’ve always stuck with ext3.

Here’s what I’ve found out:
XFS:

  • Only Linux filesystem with online defrag tools.
  • Very fast. Good with large files. Bad for small files.
  • Can’t shrink filesystem.

JFS:

  • Like XFS, but less CPU intensive.
  • No defrag tools.

Read full topic

item.title: XFS vs JFS
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:2, topic:202550”]For what use? XFS is awesome, but it’s slow and has some strange limitations that would piss me off as a home user. I’ve never tried JFS, because ext3 and Reiser are journalled anyway shrug

Have you considered Reiser?[/quote]
I never liked Reiser. Anyway, an interesting article: http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/04/28/no.body.case.ap/index.html the guy who invented reiser fs, Hans Reiser, was convicted of murdering his wife. Interesting.

Anyway, I never liked reiser. What limitations does XFS have?

Read full topic
